questiontext.text:
The table below summarises the test results obtained from a set of strength tests on the concrete produced by two laboratories. Formulate a two-sample t-test to determine whether the products produced by them are different at a significance level 5%

28 day strength (MPa)
Laboratory 1Laboratory 2
40.9054.50
41.7045.80
52.2047.80
41.8049.50
37.7050.90
45.2053.80
52.2049.70
42.7049.40
48.9052.50
47.6049.70
44.0053.60
44.5049.70


Answer:
t* = {1:NUMERICAL:=-3.75:0.01#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}
The strength of the concrete produced by the two labs are:
{1:MCV:~Equal#~=Not Equal#}

generalfeedback.text:
We set up a two-tail test of hypotheses where the hypotheses are formulated as:

Null hypothesis (Ho): the strengths of the concrete produced by the two labs are equal
Alt. hypothesis (Ha): the strengths of the concrete produced by the two labs are not equal

Mean strength of concrete produced by Lab 1: $$ \small \bar{X}_1 = 44.95 $$
Mean strength of concrete produced by Lab 2: $$ \small \bar{X}_2 = 50.57 $$

Standard dev. of strength of concrete produced by Lab 1: $$ \small \sigma_1 = 4.51 $$
Standard dev. of strength of concrete produced by Lab 2: $$ \small \sigma_2 = 2.6 $$

Sample size $$ \small n_1 = n_2 = 12 $$

Calculate the two-sample t statistics as:
$$ \small t^* = \frac{\bar{X}_1 - \bar{X}_2}{\sqrt{\frac{{\sigma_1}^2}{n_1} + \frac{{\sigma_2}^2}{n_2}}} = -3.75$$

Therefore at 5% significance level, the critical value of t (with degree of freedom: 12-1 = 11) for rejecting the null hypothesis is t* = -2.59

Hence the null hypothesis can be rejected

Note: The critical value for t can also be determined from EXCEL (or MATLAB) using the following formulas:

EXCEL: "=NORM.S.INV(0.95)" (or in general: "=NORM.S.INV(1-alpha)", where alpha is the significance level)
MATLAB: "= norminv(0.95,0,1)" (or in general: "= norminv(1-alpha,0,1)", where alpha is the significance level)
